required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Effect of Plyometric Exercises on Musculotendinous Properties
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Effect of Plyometric Exercises on Musculotendinous Properties of Quadriceps and Biceps Femoral

collaborator.agency: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico
Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul

brief_summary.textblock: Preventive and rehabilitation programs include plyometric exercises to promote agility, power, and muscle activation pattern during jumping. These exercises also are known to cause a high mechanical load that increases the risk of a musculoskeletal injury. The knowledge regarding the musculoskeletal damage result from this configuration of exercise can help to elaborate safer and effective training and rehabilitation programs. In this study, the investigators will conduct a clinical trial to determine the acute effect of plyometric exercises on damage caused on different portions of quadriceps and biceps femoral's muscles and tendons of quadriceps, and biceps femoral, and its effects on mechanical properties.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a single-arm clinical trial aiming to determine the acute effect of one session of plyometric exercises on quadriceps and biceps femoral musculotendinous properties in healthy individuals.
The sample size was determined using G*Power software considering the application of ANOVA: Repeated measures, between factors, 90% power, alpha 0.05. Data from muscle echo intensity of the rectus femoral by Muddle et al. (2019) were considered for this calculation, with an effect size 0.44. A total of 30 individuals was required for this study.
The outcomes will include the muscle and tendon quality, and mechanical properties of the tendon. The assessments will be performed at three different moments: before exercise, immediately after, and 48 hours after exercise.
The data analysis will be performed per protocol. Generalized estimating equations will be used to identify the effects of time followed by Bonferroni posthoc. When effects are found, effect sizes will be estimated. Missing data will be estimated by statistical analysis.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Single-arm design where all participants receive treatment.
study_design_info.masking_description: The statistical analyzer will be masking for the time factor.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of echo intensity of quadriceps and biceps femoral muscles
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after exercise and up to 48 hours exercise
primary_outcome.description: Muscle echo intensity will be assessed for transversal and longitudinal ultrasonography images.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline stiffness of patellar tendon
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after exercise and up to 48 hours exercise
primary_outcome.description: Patellar tendon stiffness during 5 seconds rampa contraction protocol. Patellar tendon stiffness will be estimate from force/deformation relationship of tendon.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline young modulus of patellar tendon
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after exercise and up to 48 hours exercise
primary_outcome.description: Patellar tendon young modulus during rampa contraction protocol. Young modulus will be estimate from force/deformation relationship of tendon normalized to transverse section area of tendon.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline echo intensity of quadriceps and biceps femoral tendons
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, immediately after exercise and up to 48 hours exercise
secondary_outcome.description: Tendons echo intensity will be assessed for transversal and longitudinal ultrasonography images.

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline muscle soreness of quadriceps and biceps femoral muscles
other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and up to 48 hours exercise
other_outcome.description: Soreness will be measure as treashold of pain feeling while a hand-held dynamometer apply force.

intervention.description: Plyometric exercises will be composed of vertical jumps, box jumps, half squat jumps, high straight jumps, bounding jumps, drop jumps and 10-m sprint.

overall_official.affiliation: Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul

patient_data.ipd_description: The investigators intend to publish the results in an open-access journal, indexed at the Directory of Open Access Journals, with the copyrights transferred to the authors. Details regarding the study's design and statistical plan can be obtained consulting the trial's protocol. Data on other outcomes could be requested contacting the PI.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: The individual participant dataset will become available at a public repository up to six months after the first study publication
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: A simple registration will grant access to study datasets. The website for these files is not defined at the time of registration.
